preface.title: Preface
preface.para: Many web applications require the same sequence of steps to execute in different contexts. Often these sequences are merely components of a larger task the user is trying to accomplish. Such a reusable sequence is called a flow.
Consider a typical shopping cart application. User registration, login, and cart checkout are all examples of flows that can be invoked from several places in this type of application.

Spring Web Flow (SWF) is the module of Spring that focuses on being the definitive solution for implementing flows. The Web Flow engine plugs into the Spring Web MVC platform and provides declarative flow definition language. This reference guide shows you how to use and extend Spring Web Flow.

sect1.title: What this guide covers
sect1.para: This guide covers all aspects of Spring Web Flow. It is organized into two major sections, a Users Section followed by an Architects Section. The Users Section covers implementing flows in end-user applications and working with the feature set. The Architects Section covers extending the framework and the overall architectural model.

sect1.title: What Web Flow requires to run
Where to get additional support
sect1.para: Professional "from the source" support on Spring Web Flow is available from SpringSource, the company behind Spring, and Ervacon, operated by Web Flow project co-founder Erwin Vervaet
Spring Community support is available at www.springframework.org
